channel.name: What is the correct way to init a smart contract with parameters

messages.content: The default init() won't take any parameters but if implement a standard method, what is the recommended design to prevent this method from running more than once?
if you overwrite the default `init` method, annotated with a `@method init()`, it will only run when being invoked.
Inside that method you would have to call `super.init()` to invoke the original init method (which is only supposed to run once on new deployment)
Then I guess I won't be able to provide parameters like init(param1 param2)?
the logic above can only be run once!

This is a good solution but unfortunately it requires user to run two transactions, first to deploy and then another one to initialize. Attempt to run the initialization method during the deployment will fail as "wasInitialized" does not yet exist.
@renzokuken what do you mean with "it doesn't exist yet"? an account always starts out with 8 fields of 0s as the state
@renzokuken you don't need to `get()` the state inside `initialize()`. you already know it's `0`
Also, you have a bug: you use `equals()` instead of `assertEquals()`

I am trying to prevent running `initialize` in case if it is already non-zero. Imagine initialize has been run (so its non-zero) and someone runs initialize again to somehow attack the logic of the contract.
See my code above, `requireEquals()` is what you want 🙂
it runs, I guess it confused me that in general we run `get()` beforce accessing onchain state. Thanks for clarifying!

But yeah, the error message above highlights a limitation of o1js: It doesn't take into account in-flight account updates that come earlier in the same transaction.

We made that work for nonces with some custom logic in `requireSignature()`, I wonder if we can make it work for preconditions in general, cc @Florian
Update ledger locally to what it should look like
More natural with pure UTXOs though
After thinking it through I see why you would want to initialize the state with the method, otherwise you don't get the `provedState` to be true.
provedState is a meme
It doesnâ€™t work
why
Because you can create account with vk that allows anything then switch vk at some point IIRC
No check against this in zkapp command logic
yeah right
so changing verification key should set the `proved_state` to false.
https://github.com/zeko-labs/zeko/blob/df0befe2b68d41fa3017fffc1604a049a4093e07/src/lib/transaction_logic/zkapp_command_logic.ml#L1534 @Faserisko

embeds.title: zeko/src/lib/transaction_logic/zkapp_command_logic.ml at df0befe2b6...
embeds.description: Zeko: zk-Rollup for Mina, a succinct blockchain. Contribute to zeko-labs/zeko development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: Yeah
I mean really it should be changed entirely
If the last account update was proved with the vk in it, set to true
Otherwise, set to false
This is all you need
The existing design is overly complicated for no good reason
It doesnâ€™t even need to exist though
It only exists to tell people something about the history of the account but you can check that without keeping this field on chain
Oh wow yeah, it doesn't work at all lol

@Faserisko, you can actually get the deploy account update as `zkapp.self` after calling `deploy()`. it's a bit of a hidden pattern: "the account update that resulted from the last zkapp call by this instance" is on `zkapp.self`, and even though deploy isn't a zkapp method I made sure it's the same in that case.

but yeah it should just return the AU
